awd_titl_txt: RUI,SBP: The Impact of Classroom Diversity Philosophies on the STEM Performance of Women and Underrepresented Minority Students
awd_abstract_narration:
In the U.S., women and ethnic minorities are underrepresented in STEM. To take advantage of our entire talent pool, this project bridges disciplinary findings in social psychology, education, and the scholarship of teaching and learning to understand student experiences of diversity in the STEM classroom. The research investigates the influence of environmental cues in the STEM classroom on the persistence and performance of women and underrepresented minorities in STEM. There are two main, contrasting diversity philosophies. One, colorblindness, emphasizes similarities between racial groups and promotes assimilation into the predominate culture. The other, multiculturalism, emphasizes differences between racial groups and values unique aspects of racial groups. Both philosophies are purportedly pro-diversity, yet they differentially affect women and students of color. This project innovatively investigates the impact of the use of these two philosophies by instructors in STEM classrooms. The project investigates the effect of these philosophies on feelings of inclusion, motivation to persist in study, and actual classroom performance across science and math classes. The findings of this research will provide evidence-based practices to replace well-intentioned but problematic practices to enhance diversity in STEM. These findings could help to increase the STEM talent pool in the U.S. by increasing the number of people who are included in and persist in the STEM academy.

This project tests a model of classroom diversity philosophies that emphasize either colorblind or multiculturalism by STEM instructors, which differently influence the persistence and performance of women and underrepresented minorities in these courses. Five experiments systematically investigate the direct and indirect effects of classroom diversity philosophies on STEM performance among overrepresented and underrepresented students. The experiments investigate the moderating effects of instructor race and gender on student outcomes, as well as the extent to which diversity content is integrated into the course. This project also examines mechanisms that lead to student outcomes including their perceptions of instructor attitudes and behaviors and the overall classroom climate. The experiments will employ simulated online learning environments to test the impact of diversity philosophies, controlling for individual differences in instructor characteristics. The findings of this research can inform the development of evidence-based best practices to increase persistence and performance of women and underrepresented minorities in STEM disciplines, which will expand the U.S. talent pool.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GSE: Research on Gender in S&E

por.por_cntn:
The underrepresentation of women and racial and ethnic minorities in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) is a major problem in the U.S. today. The 2021 NSF Report on Women, Minorities, and Persons with Disabilities in Science and Engineering revealed that women comprise less than 25% of bachelor?s degrees in Computer Science, Engineering, and Physics, and only slightly greater numbers in Mathematics, Statistics, and Economics. The picture is bleaker when considering intersectional identities such as underrepresented ethnic minority women, or first-generation college students.

Though this issue is complex, environmental signals of exclusion may lead students to drop out of STEM disciplines, while signals of inclusion may help them to persist despite difficulty. One such signal is the way that a classroom instructor communicates support for diverse identities and perspectives). STEM teachers may express hesitation about discussing diversity in their classrooms, perhaps because they struggle to connect diversity topics with course content or because they lack institutional support for these discussions.

Social psychological research shows that framing diversity within organizations using a colorblind philosophy (de-emphasizing differences) tends to have negative consequences for people of color compared to using a multicultural philosophy (valuing differences). For example, women students of color exposed to colorblind messages performed worse on quantitative GRE questions than those exposed to multicultural messages.

Our research extends this work to investigate the way in which instructors? framing of diversity within STEM courses impacts students? real-time learning of novel course content. We recruited a large, nationally-representative sample of 688 first-year undergraduate students and randomly assigned them to complete one of nine brief online courses in either Chemistry, Physics, or Math, with an instructor who talked about classroom diversity using Colorblind language, Multicultural Language, or did not mention diversity at all (Control Condition). Students progressed through an online course platform similar to typical virtual learning paradigms, hearing a welcome message from the instructor, reading a syllabus, watching a video lecture, and completing a quiz on the content.

Results showed that students of color scored significantly higher on the quizzes when the instructor used Multicultural language compared to Colorblind language. They also reported feeling greater belonging and viewed the instructor as less biased in the Multicultural Condition. Importantly, students of color scored similarly on the quizzes in the Control condition as in the Colorblind condition, and they viewed the Control instructor as similarly biased as the Colorblind instructor. These findings demonstrate that not talking about diversity is not an acceptable option for STEM faculty; failing to talk about diversity at all led to the same damaging consequences for students as colorblind ideologies. White students generally were not significantly affected by the diversity manipulation, though trends were often in the opposite direction as students of color. For example, White students viewed the Multicultural instructor as most biased compared to the other two conditions.

This research also included qualitative interviews of k-12 math and science teachers as well as administrators from science-based community organizations. Preliminary results highlight that STEM teachers of color have outsized effect on racial minority students? learning in part because of relationship-building and community development within the classroom. Results also show that access to science-based opportunities for k-12 public school teachers is perceived to be reduced as a result of charter and magnet schools? science specialization.

The implication of this project for STEM teachers is clear; time spent discussing and valuing diverse identities during class has clear benefits for students of color. The implication for schools is also clear; training and professional development for teachers on how to incorporate multicultural framing into their STEM classes without trivializing or tokenizing student identities is critically important.

This research contributes to the scientific literature in both social psychology and educational studies and has been published in open access format (free to the general public):

 

Good, J. J., Bourne, K. A., & Drake, R. G. (2020). The impact of classroom diversity philosophies on the STEM performance of undergraduate students of color. Journal of Experimental Social Psychology, 91I, 104026. https://doi.org/10.​1016/​j.​jesp.​2020.​104026 

Open access URL: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022103120303668 

 

Results from this project have been also presented at the annual conventions of the Society for Personality and Social Psychology, Faculty for Undergraduate Neuroscience, and the Society for Southeastern Social Psychologists, and will be submitted for presentation at the annual conferences of the American Educational Research Association and the National Association for Research in Science Teaching.
